;;;订阅;即可接收我们每周的文化推荐时事通讯。;

;
;

;从 Merchant Ivory 改编自 EM Forster 小说的经典作品到 BBC 深受喜爱的简·奥斯汀作品《 《傲慢与偏见》最伟大的古装剧是那些成功地向现代观众传达了另一个时代的情感体验的剧。在这一集中的《Critics at Large》中，特约编剧文森·坎宁安 (Vinson Cunningham)、娜奥米·弗莱 (Naomi Fry) 和亚历山德拉·施瓦茨 (Alexandra Schwartz) 讨论了他们个人最喜欢的作品，即格蕾塔·葛韦格 (Greta Gerwig) 对“;小妇人;”和简·坎皮恩的《明亮的星星》，记录了诗人约翰·济慈和范妮·布劳恩之间不幸的爱情故事——以及这种类型正在如何变化。通常，这些故事的乐趣在于它们对过去的风俗习惯的严格描述。但最近的热门剧集，包括《狄金森》 ;、”“布里奇顿”和“;The Great;”采用了明显的非历史主义，这在对话、配乐以及对种族和性的处理中很明显。主持人思考了 Apple TV+ 上的《海盗》如何与伊迪丝·沃顿的小说有所不同，因为它跳过了构成沃顿故事支柱的社会政治细节。当代的繁荣是增强了这一流派的吸引力，还是淡化了它？坎宁安说：“当我们发现过去与我们息息相关时，过去的奇异之处正是让我们感到惊奇的原因。” “如果你让一切都变得相关，那么你就消除了发现的兴奋感。”

;

;与评论家一起阅读、观看和聆听：

;

;“看得见风景的房间”（1985 年） )
;《布里奇顿》(2020-22)
;《星光璀璨》(2009)
;《卧虎藏龙》(2000)
;《狄金森》(2019-21)

;《小妇人》(2019)
;“;曼斯菲尔德庄园;，”简·奥斯汀（电影，1999 年）
;“玛丽·安托瓦内特”(2006)
;“;艺妓回忆录;，”Arthur Golden（电影，2005 年）
;“拿破仑” (2023)
;“;傲慢与偏见;”，简·奥斯汀（迷你剧，1995 年；电影，2005)
;“;海盗;，”作者：Edith Wharton（系列，2023 年）

;

;早在布莱德利·库珀在《湿热的美国夏天》中首次亮相大银幕之前，在他在《宿醉》中扮演菲尔·温内克（Phil Wenneck）之前，他想执导一位聪明的、狂饮野格酒的学校老师。此外，他想指挥。

;

;库珀在费城郊区长大，他的脑海里浮现出自己想有一天指挥一支管弦乐队的想法。正如他最近在接受 ;纽约客电台Hour;，他小时候最珍贵的财产是指挥棒。他常常在家里随着伟大的交响乐挥动手臂几个小时。现在你可以看到四十八岁的库珀站在伊利大教堂的讲台上，而伦敦交响乐团正在演奏马勒的“复活”交响曲。这部电影是“;大师;”，库珀扮演;伦纳德·伯恩斯坦;，伟大的指挥家、作曲家和教师——他在摇滚乐时代达到顶峰，但并未因此黯然失色。不知何故，他似乎从来没有比查克·贝里或约翰·列侬更现代，也从不居高临下地对待他们。伯恩斯坦深知自己是双性恋，性情反复无常，而且痴迷于艺术。凯瑞·穆里根饰演的费利西亚几乎肯定会角逐奥斯卡奖。库珀饰演的伯恩斯坦同样令人印象深刻，作为电影的导演、导演、联合制片人和联合编剧，他能够以如此准确的专注力来扮演这样一个自我消费和艺术消费的角色，这真是一个奇迹。就像伯恩斯坦本人一样，这是一个充满激情和狂野的项目。我带着媚俗的心情去看了它，然后就离开了核心。库珀和我最近交谈过；为了篇幅和清晰度，我们对对话进行了编辑。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;

;;这是一场非凡的表演、编剧和导演，我不知道你已经这样生活了多少年。 《艺术大师》的起源故事是什么？;

;

;我得把它追溯到小时候在电视机前被动画片淹没的时候——汤姆和杰瑞和兔八哥的指挥。我们的客厅里有一台电唱机，总是播放着古典音乐。那是我第一次意识到你可以上下移动你的手并发出声音。我对这种神奇力量的想法完全着迷。

;

;;它一定是麻醉剂。;

;
;
;

;小时候确实有这种感觉。我向即将到来的圣诞节的圣诞老人要了一根接力棒。

;

;;你多大了？;

;

;我一定在六岁到八岁之间。我还记得它出现的时候。我把它放在我的大学宿舍里；在研究生院，它对我来说有点像图腾。艾伦·伯斯汀 (Ellen Burstyn) 来参加了为期四个星期的研讨会，任务是创造一个角色。我为一位指挥家写了一段独白。所以从我还是个孩子的时候起，它就一直是我内心的一部分。大卫，我花了数百个小时来指挥我小时候喜欢的音乐。

;

;所以六年半前，史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格可能会拍一部关于伦纳德·伯恩斯坦的传记片。我们曾经是朋友，他碰巧知道我对指挥的痴迷。他说：“你会读这个剧本吗？你会考虑扮演伯恩斯坦吗？”我在“;一个明星的诞生;”，我发现在写作和导演时我感觉最专注于艺术。除此之外我真的不想做任何事。他不打算指挥它。我说，“听着，你能让我调查一下，看看是否有一个我可以写的剧本，一个我觉得我可以讲述的故事，让我可以参与其中并进行指挥？”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< div data-node-id="vbrwd">;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;但是当时没有现有的脚本吗？;

;

;有一个现有的脚本，由 Josh Singer 编写，他加入了，我们编写了一起创作新剧本。

;

;;接下来你做了什么？;

;

;对于拥有这部电影的派拉蒙来说，音乐权即将失效当时。我必须去见三个[伯恩斯坦]孩子——;尼娜，亚历克斯和杰米;——并试图说服他们足够信任我，给我音乐的权利。

;
;
;

;我给他们看了电影“A Star”诞生了，”我说，“这是我内心燃烧的一团大火。 。 。我永远不会做出我不相信的举动。”他们答应了。

;
;
;

;;影片的中心是伦纳德·伯恩斯坦 (Leonard Bernstein) 夫妻之间的关系和 Felicia Montealegre，这是一个非常复杂的问题。你为什么选择这个而不是伯恩斯坦生活的其他方面？;

;

;我不想拍一部传记片。你可以制作一部关于这个人的令人难以置信的纪录片——有些已经制作完成——因为那里有大量的主要镜头。但我也想利用他的影响力做正确的事。我认为我可以通过故事以外的方式来传达他的成就。例如，我觉得我可以通过让整部电影配上他的音乐来照顾他的那部分遗产。

;

;;这不是一部廉价的电影。最终的预算是多少？;

;

;我们最终的预算低于我向 Netflix 提出的要求。我想我向他们要了九千万，但我想我们最终还是没能做到这一点。对于一部 35 毫米胶片拍摄的半黑白电影来说，这是一笔巨额资金。黑白电影。

;

;;走进洛杉矶的某些房间并说，我想要九千万来拍这部电影，这是一部关于死亡经典的电影，这也一定是一件困难的事情音乐指挥家和作曲家，而不是他们更熟悉的东西。你得到了多少个否定？;

;

;它始于派拉蒙。他们说不。华纳兄弟拒绝了。苹果说不。我认为我们从未成功进入索尼。 Netflix 的斯科特·斯图伯 (Scott Stuber)——我和他坐下来，他看着我，说：“这绝对是疯了，但你的热情很有感染力，我会相信你。我信任我所信任的电影制作人。”

;

;;你不是肝碎——你是布莱德利·库珀，你要走进洛杉矶一些最大的办公室，你用什么语言来表达？得到“不”——听起来像什么？;

;

;嗯，我可以毫不犹豫地提出我相信的东西。而“不”是你变得如此熟悉的东西和。但华纳兄弟的拒绝却是一个强硬的拒绝——这有点让人受伤。我在那里拍了《一个明星的诞生》、《美国狙击手》和《小丑》，我只是想，哦，相信我，伙计们。即使它不起作用，我也不认为这对您来说看起来很糟糕，因为我过去在风险很大的项目上为您取得了如此成功。

;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< div >;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;那么他们对“否”的解释是什么？;

;
;
;

;我认为这只是合乎逻辑的。他们说的很有道理。这是一个巨大的预算。这是一个没有人会感兴趣的主题，我们无法证明它的合理性。

;

;;我听到这部电影的第一件事，除了它正在发生的环境知识之外，这是化妆的问题吗？非犹太人应该扮演犹太人吗？还有鼻子是不是太大了？等等。有关于假肢的严肃对话吗？;

;

;嗯，你所说的实际上是我们拍完电影后才出现的。当那出来时，我从来没有问过自己，因为我投入这个项目的只是爱。我用爱制作了这部电影，我尽可能地努力与爱一起工作 - 其他所有人也是如此。就兰尼（Lenny）看起来像莱尼（Lenny）而言，我知道我必须老化才能讲述这个爱情故事。他有一张美丽的标志性脸。我想，好吧，与;像Kazu Hiro这样的艺术家;，让我们创建一个混合动力，人们可以真正进入Lenny的幻想，因为我也要做声音。而且我的鼻子很大。我们的额头，鼻子，我们的眼睛 - 创造一种中间立场非常可行。实际上，我一直在寻找最少的假肢。鼻子的假肢就像是丝绸窗帘。那就是我的鼻子和鼻子之间的区别。

;

; ;真的吗？;

;

;，而且更宽。而且他的隔膜偏离。一切都与平衡有关。当我们仅尝试嘴唇和下巴，而无需用鼻子做某事时，它看起来并不像人类。有些事情发生了。然后，一旦我们平衡了它，在中间，我相信那是一个人。我和Kazu花了四年时间。我周末住在他家。因此，当出来时，我感到非常安全，以至于我们的努力，我们如何追求它是用爱完成的。现在，说，大卫，奇怪的是，亚历克斯·伯恩斯坦（Lenny's Son）给我发了一封信，我们想写一封对此回应的来信。

;

; ;回应新闻界的批评， - 称为“ ; jewface ;。” ; ; ;

;是的。我什么都没读，但我听说过。我读了这封信，然后给他打电话。我永远不会忘记它。他说：“嘿。”我说：“嘿，是布拉德利。我只是想 。 。 ”。我无法说话。我开始哭泣 - 大量，真的很难哭泣，他开始哭泣。然后我们挂了。

;

; ;您对他的感激之情？;

;
;
;

;首先，我想我也许没有意识到这是有多伤害的 - 那是所有人都看过电影。但是，只是孩子们的善良行为。

;

; ;扮演伯恩斯坦，你不想做漫画，模仿，对吗？他的声音有点像液体，低矮，贵族，但却摇摆不定。告诉我有关居住在另一个人的过程。;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;它以如何开头我听到并看电影。我总是将其视为一种音乐元素。音乐的一部分是角色和他们讲音乐的相互作用，他们的对话的旋律，尤其是Felicia和Lenny之间的旋律。我可以使用这些出色的录音带。这就是为什么我开始专注于制作电影的部分原因的一部分 - 他们的对话，尤其是他的令人陶醉的旋律。他旋律讲话。

;

;我很早就知道了，以讲述他们的关系，这将在一段时间内发生。伯恩斯坦听起来与吸烟和变老不同。他的声音完全改变了。我很早就知道我需要立即开始研究。蒂姆·莫尼奇（Tim Monich）[方言教练]和我开始在这三个不同的声音中工作 - 当他二十多岁，五十多岁时，然后他六十年代后期。

;

;

;这两种安慰模式（从先例或类比）上都假设历史是连续的，而变化是更多或更多的变化对于那些经历的人来说，逐渐越逐渐且看不见，并且人类将继续以其处理方式解决新的并发症，并以不同程度的成功来解决。所有这些假设很可能是正确的，而且使它们变得有说服力并不是不合理的。他们提供了逮捕令，以担心我们习惯于担心的事情，而不是我们甚至不知道如何担心的事情。但是他们忽略，埃里德或减少了我们可能必须面对真正的不连续性的可能性，多么牵强。

;

; doom残留案例的关键是; arignign问题; - 人造超智能可能对人类无用的前景价值观。 （这些价值观通常是不明显的，但可能包括相信生命是神圣的，人类具有尊严等的信念。）先进的AI甚至不需要敌对；冷漠同样不幸。您可以为机器的高级黑匣子提供一个清晰的指示，并发现它执行其目标而不会感性：您要求房屋清洁机器人减少不整智并杀死您的狗。缓解这种世界末日关注的方法之一是决定智力和价值观必须相关，一个足够的智力实体会吸收我们的道德关注。然而，在这种情况下，没有任何持续论证（先例或类比）可能会使我们感觉更好：我们熟悉谋杀的社会变态者的存在。谋杀的社会变态者是一种存在的证明，证明了人工智能社区中的人们称之为正交性论文，这是智力和道德在不同方面存在的观念。在过去的几十万年中，我们能够在他们面对我们完全歼灭之前遏制谋杀的社会变态者。但是，以谋杀的社会变态形式或与传统的谋杀式社会变态相关的机器超级智能可能会以前所未有的命令来指挥资源。这既是真正的糟糕，又是真正的新事物。这种存在的威胁似乎是难以置信的或遥不可及的。但是，据定义，它似乎可以尝试提供历史地役权的任何尝试。

;

;乍一看，大卫·朗奇曼（David Runciman）的“ ;The Handover: How We Gave Control of Our Lives to Corporations, States, and AIs;” seems poised to furnish just such a reassurance—to domesticate the alignment problem. Runciman, a witty and refined writer, is a professor of politics at Cambridge and a contributing editor to the ;London Review of Books;, which has also provided a home for his enlivening podcasts. He is also the Fourth Viscount Runciman of Doxford, a title that inspires not inconsiderable faith in his commitment to historical continuity. Runciman's basic argument, which unfolds in the elegantly shaggy manner of a Peripatetic seminar, is that the alignment problem is not in fact an anomaly, and that the coming singularity might best be historicized as the Second Singularity. Runciman identifies a precedent and an analogy for the alignment problem in our relationship to two other artificial agencies: the state and the corporation. This idea, in his account, first emerged in 1651, when Thomas Hobbes described ;the Leviathan; as, in Runciman's words, “a kind of robot.” Hobbes, of course, didn't call it a robot—a term that first appeared in the nineteen-twenties—but he did elaborate his vision of the state as an “Artificiall Man; though of greater stature and strength than the Naturall, for whose protection and defence it was intended.” As Runciman glosses the concept, “We assemble it in the same way we might construct any other machine of moving parts. This one is designed to resemble its creators. But it can do things we cannot. It is much more powerful than we are. That's why we built it in the first place.” The state has the supra-human advantages of durability and reliability, and serves as a means of coördination.

;

;Runciman continues, “The Leviathan is not a problem-solving machine, like a smartphone. It is a decision-making mechanism, like a set of dice. It might not give you the right answer—it will simply give you ;an; answer.” In theory, these answers reflect the will of the polity. “But because it comprises people,” he writes, “once the people get better at coming up with answers, the state should too. These dice can think for themselves.” In practice, however, Hobbes is generally regarded as a pessimist. Of the Leviathan, Runciman writes: “Its argument assumes that humans are incapable of peaceful co-existence without franchising out our decision-making power to an unaccountable higher body. At that point, we will have lost control of our fate, because whatever the state decides becomes our choice too.” In Hobbes's time—of the well-known “war of all against all”—these powers were arbitrary and absolute, but this was the price to be paid for security. Runciman readily concedes that we have spent the past few hundred years constructing better mechanisms for democratic accountability, but “the basic machinery of the modern state continues to bear the hallmark of a mechanistic understanding of politics set out nearly four centuries ago. We still have governments that take decisions for us on matters of life and death, including war and peace.” He continues,

;
;
;

;We are bound by those decisions whether we like them or not.国家有权对任何抵抗者强制执行其选择，尽管它可能不会选择使用它。大多数时候，在当代民主国家中，这些专制权力被深深地埋藏在层层法律限制和政治阻力之下，我们几乎没有注意到它们。但有时，在危机中，他们会暴露自己。 Then we must acknowledge that we are still living with the Leviathan—older, wiser, but recognisably the same as before.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Without belaboring the comparison, Runciman elaborates a case for the state, which binds human reason in a lattice of rules and procedures, as an algorithmic device. The twinned essential functions of the state—the ability to issue debt and the prerogative of war—have undergirded its durability and afforded it a capacity for long-term planning that has thus far eluded other forms of human organization. For those of us privileged enough to escape the brutality of the state in the service of imperialist extraction, the state has considerably enhanced our longevity, wealth, and happiness. But the state, even if it comprises the human, is not itself human. “Our ability to fulfil our potential—to live longer, richer, more varied lives—was made possible only by handing over some of our capabilities to artificial versions of ourselves, which do not suffer from our natural frailties. We have had to give up features of our essential humanity—some of what Arendt would call our capacity for independent action—to enjoy these other benefits,” Runciman writes.

;
;
;

;So it should come as no surprise that the state cannot be counted upon to demonstrate a commitment to human values. It has an artificial life of its own, even as it acts through us—when we are asked to kill in wartime, we are granted leave from human values. States are “persons without scruples,” Runciman notes, and we have had hundreds of years to grow familiar with this contrivance and its discontents. The machine-learning era is, in some sense, merely an extension of the mechanical one. “Let's not kid ourselves that the age of AI—with the looming challenges of black-box decision-making and algorithmic procedures whose outcomes are a mystery even to their creators—poses a unique challenge for human understanding. Just look at your own life. Do you fully understand where the group decisions come from that shape who you are?,” Runciman writes. “The fact that groups are made out of people doesn't make them any easier to see inside than other kinds of machines. The black boxes are all around us already. In one sense, at least, they ;are; us.”

;
;
;

;One of the things that make the machine of the capitalist state work is that some of its powers have been devolved upon other artificial agents—corporations. Where Runciman compares the state to a general AI, one that exists to serve a variety of functions, corporations have been granted a limited range of autonomy in the form of what might be compared to a narrow AI, one that exists to fulfill particular purposes that remain beyond the remit or the interests of the sovereign body. Corporations can thus be set up in free pursuit of a variety of idiosyncratic human enterprises, but they, too, are robotic insofar as they transcend the constraints and the priorities of their human members. The failure mode of governments is to become “exploitative and corrupt,” Runciman notes. The failure mode of corporations, as extensions of an independent civil society, is that “their independence undoes social stability by allowing those making the money to make their own rules.” There is only a “;narrow corridor;”—a term Runciman borrows from the economists Daron Acemoglu and James A. Robinson—in which the artificial agents balance each other out, and citizens get to enjoy the sense of control that emerges from an atmosphere of freedom and security. The ideal scenario is, in other words, a kludgy equilibrium.

;

;Yet we citizens of modern states have always labored under the shadow of a partly mitigated alignment problem—a “mismatch between the drives of these artificial persons and the needs of the planet,” as Runciman describes it—that provides a frame, a vocabulary, and a sense of foreboding as we seek to process the automation on the horizon. The concern about unaligned machines is that even if we can program, so to speak, their ultimate ends, we can't necessarily anticipate the instrumental subgoals they might pursue as an intermediate measure. If you instruct a machine to complete a task, the likeliest instrumental subgoal is to “gain control.” If the danger of the alignment problem seems indistinct or preposterous, Runciman suggests, ;you haven't been paying attention;.

;

;So far, so continuous. This is the point where recourse to precedent is supposed to get reassuring: given that this putatively newfangled source of distress turns out to bear a resemblance to a habitual concern, we can be confident in the human facility for survival and flourishing—or at least not utterly despondent. Except Runciman doesn't do that. Instead, he turns a standard argumentative form on its head. It's not that we can look to the past to help us solve the alignment problems of the future. It's that the alignment problems of the future help clarify our existing sense that everything is intractable and wrong. As Runciman puts it,

;
;
;

;States and corporations reflect two different sides of our contemporary fear of machines that have escaped human control. One is that we will build machines that we don't know how to switch off, either because we have become too dependent on them or because we can't find the off switch. That's states. The other is that we build machines that self-replicate in ways that we can no longer regulate. They start spewing our versions of themselves to the point where we are swamped by them. That's corporations.

;
;
;

;Runciman quite clearly believes two things. The first is that our resentful relationship to powerful machines is precedented. This might seem like good news. The second is that the recognition of this precedent does not lead to the conclusion that our relationship to powerful machines can be rendered agreeable in perpetuity. This is not good news. We have not just failed to solve the proto-alignment problem with regard to states or corporations, but, in fact, the situation has become aggravated over time. The machinery of the state has grown increasingly remote from the concerns and values of ordinary citizens, and the balance of power has tilted in the direction of ever more powerful corporations. Human values seem about as important to our current bureaucratic machinery as they would to an aloof mythical superintelligence. Just glance at our administrative dysfunction. It's all well and good to call for more democracy, but greater participation in a system that's fundamentally out of whack won't get us far.

;

;And although Runciman's plummy tone never rises to the level of alarm, his prediction is that everything is about to get worse, and this is the point in his account where AI becomes more than a useful retrospective metaphor. It would be one thing if our most pressing concern were peaceful coexistence between humans and machines. But the more relevant prospect for unease is the rapport between machines and machines—between the automata of the state and the corporation and their AI kin. Some of the potential consequences are obvious: in the use of automated weaponry, for example, or comprehensive state surveillance of the kind that China, which has directed an enormous amount of resources into AI development, is pioneering. Even in the absence of a true artificial superintelligence, we might find ourselves beset not by a single alignment problem but by multiple overlapping ones. One of Runciman's few prescriptions is that we keep foremost in mind the distinction between a machine that gives us answers and a machine that makes decisions—that we might be OK if we grant machines the status of oracles rather than overlords. This proposition discounts the possibilities that AIs can learn to deceive. (There's evidence that they already have.) But, even if we can somehow make the machines promise they'll be honest, the line between an answer and a decision is blurry, and the path from the former to the latter short. There are famous Cold War stories about military subordinates who declined the opportunity to initiate a nuclear exchange, but it remains unclear how they would have held up to the force of a state run on machine counsel. After running through a few different sci-fi scenarios of existential risk, Runciman concludes that “the bigger risk by far seems to be neither rogue individuals, nor rogue technology, nor rogue monkeys—its artificial persons gone wrong.” The combination of the artificial agency of the state with even weak forms of artificial intelligence might be just as catastrophic as the regime of a single strong AI Plenty of people have issued similar warnings before. But those have often described a plot wherein a maniacal dictator wields a loosened AI Runciman's point is that the alliance between even a democratic government and a safe-ish AI could derail civilization.

;

;

;One can, of course, object to the dark story Runciman tells.随着时间的推移，公司发生了变化。 As a consequence of the shareholder revolution, they have become more single-minded in their pursuit of profit maximization, but one doesn't have to look back very far to find examples of corporate structures that optimized for more variables than just the bottom line.在最近专门讨论这本书的播客节目中，政治理论家 Lea Ypi 提醒朗西曼，我们当前的政治和企业结构很难耗尽集体生活的可能性。 The point of a book like David Graeber and David Wengrow's “;The Dawn of Everything;,” to which Runciman delivers a rebuttal in a lengthy footnote, is that the state as machine is a historical contingency rather than an inevitable by-product of coördinated action at scale.

;

;Is that beside the point?很难说。 States might be much more than the sum of their human parts, but they're supposed to derive their legitimacy from the popular will, which means that as artificial “persons without scruples” they are nonetheless vulnerable to our appeals. They are run by people who at least in theory can be communicated with. The fact that this hasn't often been achieved doesn't mean that such an achievement is forever out of reach. The problem with an unaligned AI is that it won't care much about people one way or the other, and will remain impervious to our cries for consideration. Runciman devotes a perfunctory concluding chapter to scenarios like these, but it doesn't seem to rank highly among his priorities. This isn't because he's ruled out the likelihood of an AI doomsday, but because he considers it a failure of imagination. Members of the AI-safety community, he writes, are so taken with their own prophecies that they fail to consider how thoroughly we've already compromised our decision-making: “They overestimate the worth of human intelligence, and as a result they underestimate what stands in its way.” For Runciman, we'll be lucky if we can coax into alignment the machines we've made of ourselves, never mind the ones made of silicon. ♦

;Americans are so used to seeing history played by Americans that the oddity of it hardly registers anymore.查尔顿·赫斯顿扮演的是西班牙人的埃尔西德、希伯来人埃及人的摩西以及犹太人的宾虚——不管你信不信，他因此获得了奥斯卡奖——无论他扮演谁，也无论这个角色应该在哪里，他的中西部口音都被认为是理所当然的。 have lived.

;

;And why not?没有人指望《凯撒大帝》中的演员能说一口流利的拉丁语。小说是所有小说的前提，这个简单的事实，以及（也许正在衰落的）伴随的事实，即大多数电影明星都是在美国诞生的，足以解释这一现象。 Indeed, the whole point and rationale—the raison d'être, as we say in English—of the theatrical arts is to extend our circles of compassion through acts of creative empathy: we ;want; people who are unlike the characters they play to inhabit them so that in acts of sympathetic resonance we too expand ourselves. It's why we love Laurence Olivier's Shylock, or, for that matter, Russell Crowe's gladiator.

;

;Yet, when one has something, if no more than a big toe, resting in another culture, the oddity resonates. Though Joaquin Phoenix plays Napoleon, for the most part ably, in ;Ridley Scott;'s much talked-of ;new movie; of the Emperor's life and battles, it's still disconcerting that he says his lines not only in English but more or less with exactly the same accents—and using exactly the same slightly paralyzed set of expressions—with which he ;inhabited; Johnny Cash.他的角色的演员阵容仍然是他的角色的演员阵容，菲尼克斯以经典的电影明星方式进行了调整，但角色之间没有显着的差异； he is no Lon Chaney, nor nearly an Olivier, inventing a new face and voice for each role.

;

;This oddity has not been missed in the French reception to the film. Almost all French commentators italicize the ambiguities of Napoleon's historical role—was he the reincarnation of Alexander the Great or the sinister precursor of Hitler? Perhaps the sole exception is the far-right polemicist and onetime Presidential candidate ;Éric Zemmour;, who contributed a laudatory story to the far-right magazine ;Valeurs actuelles; with the cover line “L'empereur anti-woke ”。不管多么不可思议，“觉醒”已经成为法国争论中无处不在的借用词，尤其是在反美极右翼分子中。 You might suppose that those who believe that America is colonizing French culture would find a French word around which to organize their disdain, but they don't.他们轻蔑地使用美国这个词，但他们确实这么做了。 It's as if, in anti-French polemics, we insisted on condemning their undue ;sang-froid;. Apparently, no one has stopped to consider the power of a culture that forced you to borrow its language to condemn it.

;But most of the arguments against “Napoleon” were about language in another way, and more nettled. “这部电影并没有因为这两个人的事实而感到困扰。 。 。 warring factions speak the same language (English), which never ceases to feel odd,” a film critic at ;Le Monde; ;wrote;. “Directed by a Briton who has long reigned over Hollywood, ;Napoleon; is a film that essentially reminds us that the Empire has changed hands since Waterloo.” （用这个略显精妙的公式，批评者的意思是好莱坞像法国人一样统治着世界。） 当然，人们只能想象美国人看到一部关于亚伯拉罕·林肯的生活的极其昂贵和精心制作的电影会有什么感觉。 Gérard Depardieu in the lead, and with wartime Washington perfectly realized and Gettysburg thrillingly re-created, but with everyone from bedroom to battlefield muttering and roaring in guttural French and using idiomatic French expressions to summon up the American ones—“;Ah, alors!;,” “;Sacré bleu;,” “;Monsieur le President;,” and so on.这样的电影将传达“拿破仑”在法语母语人士中引发的超现实文化错位，更不用说意想不到的喜剧了。这与其说是一个棘手的文化挪用问题，不如说是一个更直接的喜剧不协调问题。 Though languages do not, in truth, ;enclose singular domains of meaning;, there are still patterns of behavior, ways of addressing the world, acculturated norms of discourse and style, that affect all members of a linguistic practice.

;To take one subtle and circular example, the French aristocrats in “Napoleon” are played mostly by English actors affecting upper-crust English accents that rather betray the equivalent speech pattern in French, which is not clipped and reserved but sonorous and rhetorically sinuous. (The foreign minister Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand would not hesitate to orate at his emperor, rather than interrogate him politely, as he does here.) ;
;

;But this means that, when an actual British upper-cruster, in this case the Duke of Wellington, played by Rupert Everett, appears, he has to go ;way; over the top in order to distinguish himself from the clipped Brits playing the French.他必须成为英国上流社会的一种令人愤慨的讽刺，全是哼哼和冷笑，这样（这是圆形的部分）他最终的表现就像法国人传统上讽刺的马脸和毫无幽默感的英国人一样，就像, for instance, the Astérix comics.

;
;
;

;It's the fiendishly hidden English prejudices of the movie, though, that the French find most pernicious. “This film was made by an Englishman” was the historian Patrice Gueniffey's blunt ;verdict; in the magazine ;Le Point;, “and openly anti-French.” (Gueniffey has written two mostly ;admiring; ;books; about the Emperor.) The many historical anomalies in the movie—which are bound to be there—are viewed with his suspicious eye as part of a pattern of anti-French sentiment.拿破仑并没有像电影开头那样接近处决玛丽·安托瓦内特，这使得拿破仑的威权主义似乎是对恐怖统治的反应，只有在非常普遍的意义上才是正确的：希特勒的崛起与之前的魏玛通货膨胀有关——这个序列中有许多缺失的步骤。 But this is, as in both Edmund Burke and “A Tale of Two Cities,” the traditional British way of imagining the revolution: the bloody-minded French need a boss, or they go mad.

;

;Napoleon's expedition to Egypt, meanwhile, is represented as a kind of creepy mix of loot-taking and pyramid-destroying, though in fact Bonaparte and his men never aimed cannons at the peaks of pyramids, as they do here, and the expedition came complete with an earnest set of scholars, including the great Vivant Denon, and led eventually to Champollion's decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphics. The Rosetta stone, taken from Egypt by Napoleon, was in turn taken from him by the Brits—it still lives in the British Museum—and so Napoleon's sagacious purpose in Egypt is presumably deliberately left out of the “British” movie.

;

;Worse still, from the French view, the Emperor is portrayed as a clumsy lover. One of the current Bonapartist pretenders—there are two, with different lineage—the Prince Murat, a descendant of Napoleon's brother-in-law, was so offended by this that he was moved to write indignantly in ;Le Figaro; on behalf of the Emperor's erotic equipoise. （有两个拿破仑与约瑟芬发生性关系的难看的场景，拿破仑衣着整齐，从后面做爱。）王子抗议说，皇帝的做爱“像一个笨拙、笨拙和受惊的小男孩”，但随后他补充道，难怪，因为他自始至终都被描绘成“笨拙、幼稚、残忍、优柔寡断和软弱”。 (The pretender still recommended the film, seemingly on the ground that getting people thinking Bonaparte is always a good idea.)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet what truly offends French opinion about the film is a very French thing: the failure to sufficiently dramatize administrative excellence.拿破仑是一个平庸的将军，但却是一位出色的国家管理者，这是一个合理的违反直觉的例子——他输掉了关键战役，并做出了注定要失败的决定，试图从海上入侵英国，然后从陆路入侵俄罗斯，但他催生的民法典仍然存在今天，他的任人唯贤、“向人才开放”的职业理念确实是新颖且持久的。影片没有明确说明的一件事是，拿破仑周围的人已经从军中晋升，而他的将军和元帅则像很可能是科西嘉岛的痞子作为波旁贵族。 Napoleon was a hands-on manager and promoter of men—he once even wrote sympathetically about a lowly corporal with a drinking problem.

;

;Gueniffey also insists that the casualty numbers that run in the credits at the end of “Napoleon,” intended to make one aware of the horror inflicted by the man whom the film has just spent the past two and a half hours heroizing, are greatly inflated. In any case, the perpetual choice between the two Napoleons—the revived Alexander or the premature Hitler—will not be settled here. The actor Albert Dieudonné, who played Bonaparte in Abel Gance's legendary five-and-a-half-hour silent version, was buried in his Napoleonic costume. Phoenix seems likelier to go to his grave as Johnny Cash.

;

;Still, the cult of the Emperor won't end, and even an often awkward film can't end it.在几个场景中，拿破仑在扮演皇帝的同时也被艺术家描绘，这部分是真实的：魅力十足的暴君吸引了当时更优秀的艺术家。大卫、席里柯和安格尔都是他的直接追随者——这是当代独裁者无法比拟的，尽管也许只是因为周围有更好的艺术家阶层。 After all, Napoleon was able to fool many men of genius into thinking that he might be the bringer of republican ideals, as with Beethoven and the “Eroica,” written in Napoleon's honor until Beethoven figured out who he really was. (“Now, too, he will tread under foot all the rights of Man, indulge only his ambition; now he will think himself superior to all men, become a tyrant!”)

;

;When Napoleon fell and the French painters sighed and went to work for the mediocre royals who followed him, they did not do good work—until Delacroix's “Liberty Leading the People,” made for the revolution of 1830, restored the nobility of revolutionary painting, which retains its own peculiar and glamorous aura to this day. But, then, the romantic glory of revolution is perhaps the most distinct cultural accent left to us by the era and its Emperor. It explains why Napoleon movies, never made well, will never stop being made, in whatever language lies at hand. ♦

;One of the most graceful experiences I've had at the movies this year is the last part of “Monster,” the drama directed by Hirokazu Kore-eda that's currently in theatres, but it takes a saintly patience to sit through the hour-plus of action that precedes it. “Monster” is coy and cagey, its story constructed in three parts whose narrative boundaries are sharply drawn. Each centers on a different character in the story, but this isn't a movie of ambiguity; it's one of ambiguity dispelled and prejudices thereby laid bare. Reader beware: no sensible discussion of the film can entirely avoid spoilers, given the dramatic twists that Kore-eda doses out as if they were time-release medication for the viewer's moral failings. Yet these pivots hardly matter. What matters in “Monster” isn't the gamesmanship built into its structure but the imaginative richness, the emotional immediacy, and the vital performances that are concentrated in its extended third section.

;

;The first part follows a widow named Saori (Sakura Ando), whose son, Minato (Soya Kurokawa), a fifth grader, complains of being insulted and even physically abused by his homeroom teacher, Mr. Hori (Eita Nagayama). The second part depicts the same events, this time centered on Hori's view of them. The third, focussing on Minato himself, dispels the mysteries of the previous two sections, and in so doing reveals the narrow misjudgments of the adult characters, who hadn't had the benefit of knowing the full story. It also overturns misunderstandings that viewers will have formed, led on by the earlier sections' calculated red herrings.

;

;The movie, written by Yûji Sakamoto, is set in a small provincial city. A high-rise building in the center of town is on fire and becomes a subject of gossip. A customer at a dry cleaner where Saori works mentions to her that one floor of it houses a hostess bar that Hori is said to frequent—inappropriate conduct for a teacher. Meanwhile, her son, Minato, is manifestly troubled and tells her that Hori pulled his ear, bloodied his nose, and called him a monster with a pig's brain. When Saori goes to the school to complain, she's met with deferentially polite stonewalling—evasions and deflections, vague apologies and brazen lies. The discussion gets heated, and Hori accuses Minato of bullying another boy in the class named Yori (Hinata Hiiragi).

;
;
;

;In the second part, laying out Hori's romantic life, his sense of persecution by Minato's mother, and his humiliation over the accusations, Kore-eda tweaks the drama to signal more clearly endemic social ills: the stifling of free expression by an elaborate code of proprieties; the way that narrow administrative rules predicated on the value of self-restraint enforce a norm of silence; the exacerbating role of other traditional forms of patriarchal, macho oppression. The indictment is powerful but would be more so were it evoked more subtly with a wider range and a finer grain of action—or, alternatively, more candidly, with denunciatory vehemence. Instead, the film lands somewhere in between, with a feeling of one-to-one correspondence in the way that a given action or utterance pins a given idea to the screen, allowing no nonconforming excess of observation or of emotion.

;

;The problem with information being dosed out like this goes beyond a viewer's uneasy feeling of being toyed with by a filmmaker.这种策略实际上也影响了电影制片人，强加了一种狭隘的视野，一种缩小视角和想象力的戏剧性目的论。 In the movie's first section, Saori's mounting sense of trouble with Minato offers a strong undercurrent of narrative energy, but Kore-eda is forced to let it go to waste. Lest too much be revealed too soon, he truncates scenes of mother-son discussions—and, similarly, of Saori's confrontations with Hori and other school officials.这些对抗的言语攻击和招架都是精心设计的，表演也经过精心校准。 there's a subtle fervor in the way Ando modulates Saori's mounting rage, and Yûko Tanaka, as a school principal harboring a shame of her own, conveys tension lurking behind imperturbably rigid formality.然而一次又一次，当这些场景达到紧张的关键时刻时，它们就结束了。在观看过程中，我最常对自己说的话就是对被悬吊着感到困惑；毕竟，角色如何摆脱戏剧性的僵局或潜在的灾难与他们如何陷入困境同样重要。 Instead, Kore-eda cuts and cuts to fit the Procrustean demands of his scheme.

;

;The revelations of the third section, retroactively clarifying the story, turn out to be far more than mere plot points. This part of the film, centered on Minato's friendship with Yori, is manifestly the one in which Kore-eda and the screenwriter Sakamoto are deeply invested, the one that they fill with heart and in which their imagination and curiosity range freely at last. It's a friendship that Minato has trouble avowing, because Yori—slight and impish, with a high-pitched voice—is the target of bullying. Minato fears being associated with him, even as he takes exceptional and reckless steps to defend him. The two boys share in wondrous and gleeful games of fantasy. There are intensely dramatic moments reminiscent of some of the most agonizing scenes in “;Moonlight;,” including a sublime fillip of revolt against oppressive paternal authority. In another scene with Minato, Yori contemplates the end of the universe and the nature of time in childlike terms involving food, excrement, and their own birth; Kore-eda and Sakamoto display a calmly spectacular sensitivity to a bright child's speculative temperament and strong memory, and Hiiragi produces one of the most exquisite moments of any recent performance by a child actor. By now, the writing is so fine-grained and so varied, the direction so attentive, and the performances so sympathetic, that the third section plays nearly like a film in itself, one that's a far deeper and richer experience than the whole into which它适合。 ♦

;

;

;

;;锻炼：;策划、操纵。
; ;休息：;睁着一只眼睛睡觉。

;

;要获得表演大师班，托德·海恩斯 (Todd Haynes) 的新电影“;五月十二月;，”到达Netflix 将于 12 月 1 日上映。朱丽安·摩尔饰演的格雷西是二十年前小报丑闻的对象，当时她与一个十几岁的男孩（现在是她的丈夫）发生了关系。娜塔莉·波特曼饰演伊丽莎白，一位在电影中扮演格雷西的女演员，并去研究格雷西看似井然有序的家庭生活。摩尔和波特曼都在我们的银幕上出现了几十年，并且都获得了奥斯卡最佳女主角奖。但在《五月十二月》中，每个人都处于自己的巅峰，这部电影在某种程度上是关于表演本身的。格雷西在伊丽莎白面前展现出最美的一面，而在私下里，她显得更加粗鲁和陌生。伊丽莎白假装和蔼可亲，同时吸收了格雷西的心理（这是一项比看起来更棘手的任务），而波特曼则对拍摄爱情场景的模糊界限进行了一段令人难忘的独白。看着这两位出色的表演者表演出色的表演者，您会想：我们一直在表演多少？

;
